de.aitools.aq.textextraction
Class PsConverter

java.lang.Object
  de.aitools.aq.textextraction.TextExtractor
      de.aitools.aq.textextraction.PsConverter

public class PsConverter
extends TextExtractor

An implementation of TextExtractor to convert PS files to plain text.

On Linux there are several ways or programs to convert PS files to plain text. The following is a list of these methods and some notes about whether their usage is recommended or not and why.

  • ps2txt is a symbolic link to ps2ascii. Here is an excerpt from its manpage: ps2ascii doesn't look at font encoding, and isn't very good at dealing with kerning, so for PostScript (but not currently PDF), you might consider pstotext.
  • The manpage to pstotext says: pstotext reads one or more PostScript or PDF files, and writes to standard output a representation of the plain text that would be displayed if the PostScript file were printed. [...], pstotext always translates to the ISO 8859-1 character code.
    Although the output is satisfying the last statement is a know-out criterion, because we need UTF-8 encoding. So lets come to the next approach.
  • Another way is to transcode PS files into a format that can be already converted to plain text files with good quality. Since we have such a solution for PDF to plain text, the pipeline PS > PDF > TXT sounds promising. On Linux you can find again two programs converting PS to PDF files.
    • ps2pdf is the Ghostscript related program, which states to be very close to Adobe's Acrobat Distiller (see manpage).
    • The second tool is pstopdf, which seems to be a complete independent implementation.
    Finally I decided to take ps2pdf for this converter implementation, because this program is based on Ghostscript, which is the de-facto standard library under Linux for PDF conversion stuff. The last ps2pdf update was 2010 (compared to 2006 for pstopdf) and thus more up-to-date.

TODO PDF to PS conversion: pdf2ps or pdftops > take ps2pdf and why
